utterances: Well, I think there have been a number of instances when bias has been demonstrated within the Mueller probe; also, the manner in which the team has been put together, the relationship between Mr. Mueller and Mr. Comey; and then finally, some of the details of the intelligence memo that we hope is made public this week would seem to indicate that no prosecution could ever be brought from the Mueller probe.
And thus, its utility has been outlived.
Could you cite a single example of bias?
Sure.
Andrew Weissman, the No. 2 member of the Mueller probe, attended the Hillary Clinton election night party.

You would think with all the talented prosecutors to be asked throughout the federal system, we could likely assemble a team without having to pick the people who were engaged in the 2016 election to the extent that they would be at one of the candidates' election night parties.
Oh, my God, yes, absolutely.
Applying those skills of observation in an environment like a topless club on Bourbon Street actually became very practical for me.
I learned a lot about people and how to interact with people.
About six months ago, Patrick moved to Santa Cruz, California, where his wife is studying Chinese medicine.
Today, he has a second interview for a job as a field rep for the local state assemblyman.
That's the job that I want.
Now, barring that, I want to be involved with the community, basically.
I'll keep trying to find a job with the government here or find some other local, community-based organization and try to find a job with them.
Patrick Mulhearn, looking for work in Santa Cruz, California.
If you're also out of work, looking, and have a story to tell, write us.
Just send an email to daydreaming@npr.org and put ""Help Wanted"" in the subject line.
We'll be sharing some of your job-hunting tales in the coming weeks.
Again, that address: daydreaming@npr.org.
Steve Proffitt, NPR News.
(Soundbite of song ""Mr.
President (Have Pity On The Working Man)"")
(Singing) It is cold and the wind is blowing, We need something to keep us going.
Mr. President, have pity on the working man.
Of course, this last week has been kind of a nightmare for Boeing and its new 787 Dreamliner.
In three separate incidents in as many days, airline carriers reported problems with brakes, with fuel leaks and a battery fire.
The U.S.
Department of Transportation has announced a comprehensive review of the new plane.
Joining us now to talk about Boeing's new 787 is Joe Nocera, op-ed columnist for The New York Times, and our man on finance and other matters.
Joe, thanks very much for being with us.
And thanks for having me, Scott.
By all accounts, of course, this is one of the most technologically advanced planes ever built, and Boeing took their time designing and building it.
So how do they get it into operation - and it starts springing a fuel leak?
Well, what Boeing would say is gosh, this stuff is complicated.
And of course, it is.
And it has six electrical systems; you know, hydraulic power's now been switched to electrical power; and it's got computers and batteries, and so on and so forth.
So what Boeing would say is, we're still working out the little glitches.
On the other hand, if you're flying one of these things and these glitches cause you not to fly, or to wait for four hours to fly - as happened, also, this week - you're not very happy about it.
Yeah.
I mean, if you look at your ticket and see it's Dreamliner, this past week, you would wonder, oh, am I ever going to take off?
Or, when we get in the air - you know, are we going to be losing fuel?
Well, it is - you know, it is three years late.
It was supposed to come to market in 2008.
It came to market in 2011, and a large part of the reason for that delay was precisely because it was really complicated, and it was not unlike any other airplane that had ever come before.
It has, you know, lightweight parts, and it has - it's fuel-efficient; and it's this, that and the other thing.
And I should also point out, Scott, that these problems have had zero effect on Boeing's sales.
Well, that's important.
What's your estimation of that?
Has the company just addressed it so powerfully?
No, that's not the reason at all.
The reason is that we have an aging fleet worldwide, and so companies need airplanes.
And Boeing and Airbus made very different bets on what the world was going to need.
Airbus bet on - giant aircraft that hauls 6- or 700 people.
And Boeing made a bet that the world wanted smaller planes that went point to point, that had 200 to 250 people.
As a result, Airbus's backlog is about 250 airplanes.
Boeing's backlog is about 850 airplanes.
So if you cancel a Boeing order 'cause you're mad about these problems, or you want them sooner, you don't have any other place to go.
And what is your estimation of how Boeing has handled the problem so far?
Well, they're in a tricky spot.

On the one hand, in their heart of hearts, they believed that these problems are really small; that it's not putting anybody at risk; and it's just kind of a teething process, as they like to say, with a brand-new aircraft.
But they can't say that out loud because then they sound callous and uncaring.
And so when the Department of Transportation and the FAA say, well, we're going to investigate the electrical systems, you know, Boeing can't say, don't worry, we're going to fix all this.
They have to say, we're on board.
And so it's basically been a headache that they think is not quite justified, but they can't say that out loud.
Now that - you've, of course - have covered these kind of cases before, where corporations have to handle questions from the public.
And this is a hard line to finesse.
On the one hand, you have to be concerned about the problem - but not so concerned you leave people to be alarmed about it.
Well, take another example, which doesn't have anything to do with Boeing.
Take Toyota and its accelerator problem, which they just paid a billion dollars to settle lawsuits.
You know, it basically turned out that the problem with the accelerator had nothing to do with the electrical components, or any other components, of Toyota.
It had to do with - they put the mat in wrong, and sometimes people just, you know, put their foot in the wrong place.
Nonetheless, to get this problem behind them, they had to pay a billion dollars.
Now, Boeing's not going to have anything like that because they haven't had crashes; they probably won't have crashes - at least around these sets of problems.
So it's just trying to kind of keep its head down, play the good citizen, and get through it.
Joe Nocera of The New York Times; speaking to us from the studios of the Radio Foundation in New York.
Thanks very much, Joe.
Thank you, Scott.
It's time again for your letters.
And on my right hand side, producer Christopher Johnson.
Hey, Christopher.
Hey, Farai.
How are you doing?
I'm good.
What do we got?
Well, first up, a letter inspired by our letters.
Jeremy Burley(ph) in Los Angeles wrote to say this: I'm a subscriber to the NEWS & NOTES podcast, and somehow I missed listening to this segment on punk musician Tamar-kali.
However, I heard another listener's letter mentioning it.
I went back to listen and was thoroughly pleased.
I have very eclectic musical tastes, from rock, pop and metal to R&B, hip-hop, jazz and classical.
I applaud your spotlighting black musicians from all genres.
Please continue to explore the surprising level of diversity in black music that lies beyond mainstream expectations and stereotypes.
So I put up a PayPal button, which was very effective.
And that kept me going.
So, after the first long trip to Iraq, which lasted about eight months, I went over to Afghanistan and just continued to report from, you know, based on viewer support.
And why do you do it?
Well, I lost several friends to the war.
One friend was a Polish writer named Biatta Pavlick (ph).
She was killed in the Bali bombing in which about 200 people were killed.
And then I lost a friend - and I was in Special Forces myself - lost an old Special Forces friend in Iraq on March 30th, 2004, Richard Ferguson.
Killed in Samarra.
And then the next day I lost another friend, Scott Helvenston, who was one of the Blackwater contractors murdered in Fallujah when they mutilated the bodies.
So I went to those funerals in Colorado and Florida.
And then after - when I was at those funerals X military people kept telling me, you should go to the war and report on it, because the story is not being told.
And I said, no thanks, I'm not going to the war, and it's just not happening.
And so - but that was April of 2004 when, you know, we started to flatten Fallujah the first time, which was obviously a massive over-reaction.
And then we - you know, the Abu Ghraib photos broke that month, and clearly, something was going wrong.
Then in November of 2004, you know, the second flattening of Fallujah, Operation Phantom Fury, began.
And that was when I realized that we were losing the war, and so I went there in December and I stayed most of 2005.
And you were, as your comments suggest, highly critical of how the war was being conducted, but very supportive of those fighting it.
Right.
The troops' professionalism was obvious.
I mean, that was very clear.
It was actually much higher than I would have ever expected.
They were doing a fine job, and they were trying to morph to the situation as it morphed.
But you know, when we first went in, we didn't - nobody expected, or few people expected, there would be such a massive insurgency, or so many insurgencies, actually.
And so it took awhile to adjust to that situation which they have effectively done by now.
And you are, at least according to your op-ed in the Wall Street Journal the other day, an unabashed supporter of the surge.
Yeah, well, it's been very effective, and not just the surge, but the Anbar Awakening, which began in 2006 was also part of the growing success.

But the surge and also the change in the tactics, in 2007 in particular, pushing the troops out to combat outposts, or what they call ""COPS,"" has been very effective in generating intelligence which has been used to target terrorists, and also the civic-action programs have been very effective.
General Petraeus, responsible for, at least, many of those innovations, and again, you are a supporter of his.

We just heard, today, news from Secretary of Defense Robert Gates that General Petraeus will be promoted and will be the head of CENTCOM now, overall in charge of Iraq, but not the guy on the ground with the troops there.
I know you've been in this country for the past ten days, but what do you think the affect on moral of U.S.
forces might be?
I think it's a very good move to move General Petraeus to CENTCOM.
I first heard about that about three days ago, and I was curious if he would actually be moved to CENTCOM, but I saw on C-SPAN this morning that he is and Odierno's going to...
That's Ray Odierno, his deputy.
Right, is taking his position, taking Petraeus' old position in Baghdad.
But I think moving Petraeus to CENTCOM is very good, because that also has responsibility for Afghanistan, and the war is going very poorly in Afghanistan.
So I think it could be a very good thing.
And I gather you're thinking of heading to Afghanistan next.
Right.
I went to Afghanistan first in 2006 and reported.
There, I was actually un-embedded.
I did not go with any - U.S.
- any military at all.
I left my gear actually in Iraq.
I'm going back there shortly, and then after that, over to Afghanistan.
Well, let's get some listeners involved in the conversation.
Again, our guest is Michael Yon, blogger and photographer in Iraq, and author of the book ""Moment of Truth in Iraq."" He's here with us in the Newseum.
Email us, talk@npr.org.
And let's start with Bob and Bob's with us from Nevada City in California.
Yeah.
It's Rob, but that's all right.
Oh, I apologize for that.
OK, I do have a question.

One, it seems you were embedded in Iraq and I was wondering if the troops, even if they have time for it, do they have access to alternative points of view in the media, such as C-SPAN or other media?

They do, on some of the - what they call ""nipper lines,"" where the Internet connections that are - civilian Internet connections, some sites are blocked, but mostly everything is open, because they can buy their own Internet connections - they can buy their own satellite links.
So they...
Can it be like cable television that's being shown in barracks is anything besides Fox or - shown?
